description: From Middle English ha (interjection). Compare Old Norse há (interjection), Middle Low German ha, hā (interjection), Old High German aha, hei (interjection).

verbs.description: haw (third-person singular simple present haws, present participle hawing, simple past and past participle hawed)

entries.meaning: To stop, in speaking, with a sound like haw; to speak with interruption and hesitation.

description: From Middle English hawe, from Old English haga (“enclosure, hedge”), from Proto-Germanic *hagô (compare West Frisian haach, Dutch haag, German Hag (“hedged farmland”), Norwegian Bokmål hage (“garden”)), from Proto-Indo-European *kagʰom (compare Welsh cae (“hedge”), Latin caulae (“sheepfold, enclosure”), cohum (“strap between plowbeam and yoke”), Russian кош (koš, “tent”), коша́ра (košára, “sheepfold”), Sanskrit कक्ष (kakṣa, “curtain wall”)), from *kagʰ- 'to catch, grasp' (compare Welsh cau (“to clasp”), Oscan kahad (“may he seize”).

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Something that has little value or importance; a whit or jot.

description: Assumed to be interjectory, but compare Old English hawian (“to observe, look”)

verbs.description: haw (third-person singular simple present haws, present participle hawing, simple past and past participle hawed)

entries.meaning: (of an animal) To turn towards the driver, typically to the left.
examples: This horse won't haw when I tell him to.

entries.meaning: To cause (an animal) to turn left.
examples: You may have to go to the front of the pack and physically haw the lead dog.

description: Late Middle English (denoting a discharge from the eye), of uncertain origin. Perhaps related to Etymology 2 above, describing a berry.

entries.meaning: (countable, anatomy) The third eyelid, or nictitating membrane.
(uncountable) A disease of the nictitating membrane.
